ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This is the course that allowed for me to tap into a certain kind of academic reading, analysis, and discussion that I've hoped to find during my time in graduate school. It provided for a close-read on a wide swath of schools of thought, philosophy, and approaches to critical thought and apply that to my work and personal art practice. That has proved invaluable and certainly useful for beyond Yale for a long time to come.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strengths are numerous: the readings are engaging in a broad amount of schools of thought on different subject matters and are related back to a more specific discussion through the lectures and discussion in the classroom. Perhaps one of the only weaknesses is that it is sometimes challenging to keep up with the note-taking during class, but as a song I like goes "all pain is small change in the cost of wonder." That said, I think some of the readings were much more dense than others, which made accessing the core ideas a bit more difficultyagain, not really a weakness, just something that took more time in relating it to the class as a whole as opposed to individual sessions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Without question would recommend this course (and instructor) to every peer, and in fact, I have already done so numerous times. It facilitated a challenging level of discourse and thought that only served to enhance all of my other modes of practice at Yale and beyond.
